iGilbert Drama ($) Rent

Also opening in theaters on December 17 following a debut on the fall festival circuit, Maggie Gyllenhaal's directorial debut—which was recently named best picture of 2021 at the Gotham Awards—is an adaptation of the 2006 novel of the same name by Elena Ferrante (the Italian author best known for My Brilliant Friend). Olivia Colman stars as a woman whose solo summer seaside vacation turns sour when she becomes obsessed with another family whose activities trigger unhappy memories of her own past as a young mother. Gyllenhaal also wrote the script and enlisted a strong cast that also includes Dakota Johnson, Paul Mescal, Jessie Buckley, Ed Harris, and Peter Sarsgaard.

Temuera Morrison (playing Boba Fett) and Ming-Na Wen (as fellow bounty hunter Fennec Shand) star in a spinoff from the hit Star Wars streaming series The Mandalorian that is set (at least in part) on Tatooine. Robert Rodriguez, who directed the Mandalorian episode that saw the return of Fett (a character that was first seen in The Empire Strikes Back—or, if you prefer, the Star Wars Holiday Special), will direct multiple episodes of the new series and serve as a producer alongside Jon Favreau and Dave Filoni (both of whom will also direct episodes, as will fellow Mandalorian director Bryce Dallas Howard).

▣ Mass Trailer Drama ($) Rent

Debuting on VOD today after a theatrical run, Fran Kranz's directorial (and screenwriting) debut could be an Oscar contender in multiple categories after receiving terrific reviews for its taut, actor-driven story about the aftermath of a school shooting in which the parents of one of the victims sit down for a conversation with the parents of the shooter. Ann Dowd, Jason Isaacs, Martha Plimpton, and Reed Birney star.

If you only know the late Bob Einstein from his role as Marty Funkhouser on Curb Your Enthusiasm, you are missing out on quite a bit of his storied career. Danny Gold's documentary will use archival clips and new interviews (with Einstein's brother Albert Brooks plus Larry David, Steve Martin, David Letterman, and more) to fill you in on the details, including a look at his Emmy-winning work on The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour and performances as his long-lived stuntman alter-ego Super Dave Osborne.

Adam McKay's first feature film since 2018's Vice is a comedy about two minor astronomers (Leonardo DiCaprio and Jennifer Lawrence) who believe they've made a startling discovery: A comet is about to collide with Earth. But now comes the hard part: convincing the world that they are right. Does Meryl Streep play the President of the United States? Why yes, she does. The huge ensemble also features Jonah Hill, Timothée Chalamet, Cate Blanchett, Ariana Grande, Tyler Perry, Gina Gershon, Chris Evans, Matthew Perry, Melanie Lynskey, Mark Rylance, Ron Perlman, and Kid Cudi. Don't Look Up will open in theaters on December 10 prior to today's streaming debut, just in case anyone is considering nominating Streep for an Oscar. (It never hurts to try.)

Featuring original music by Lin-Manuel Miranda, Disney's 60th animated feature makes a quick jump to Disney+ after just one month in theaters.

The third straight critically acclaimed film from writer-director Mike Mills (Beginners, 20th Century Women) heads to VOD today after a month in theaters. It's a biitersweet, black-and-white drama about a journalist (Joaquin Phoenix) who takes his young nephew on a cross-country trip while the boy's mother (Gaby Hoffman) cares for her ailing partner (Scoot McNairy), who is suffering from mental health issues.

Sure, half of this holiday special will consist of a new concert performance by the band. But what makes it unique is the other half of the show: a '90s sitcom spoof called "All My Friends" that finds actors (and, in one case, a puppet) playing members of LCD Soundsystem. That cast includes Macaulay Culkin, Aparna Nancherla, and Jon Daly, while Eric Wareheim plays bandleader James Murphy (and also directs the special).

The Masked Singer Christmas Singalong Reality/Music 8p

Keanu Reeves, Carrie-Anne Moss, and Jada Pinkett Smith return for the first Matrix film since 2003. The fourth entry in the franchise finds Lana Wachowski directing solo for the first time and also stars Yahya Abdul-Mateen II (as Morpheus, the role originated by Laurence Fishburne), Jonathan Groff, Neil Patrick Harris, Christina Ricci, Priyanka Chopra Jonas, and Jessica Henwick. It will stream for one month on HBO Max beginning today, when it is also released in theaters.

▣ Being the Ricardos Trailer Drama Prime Video

Streaming on Amazon following a brief theatrical run (which begins December 10), the latest feature from writer-director Aaron Sorkin unfolds over the course of one week during the filming of the famed sitcom I Love Lucy. Nicole Kidman (rather improbably) plays Lucille Ball, while Javier Bardem portrays Desi Arnaz. As for Fred and Ethel? That would be J.K. Simmons and Nina Arianda.

The Murder of Gabby Petito: Truth, Lies and Social Media Trailer Reality Peacock

Writer-director Lauren Hadaway based her feature debut on her own experiences as a competitive college rower. Tracking freshman Alex Dall (Orphan's Isabell Fuhrman) as she obsesses over making the top varsity boat, The Novice won multiple awards at this year's Tribeca Festival, including the top prize for best narrative feature (U.S.). It also plays in theaters beginning today.

Rolling Like Thunder Documentary 8p

Making a simultaneous streaming and theatrical debut (and not to be confused with another 2021 movie also called Swan Song), this near-future drama from first-time feature director Benjamin Cleary stars Mahershala Ali as a husband and father who is diagnosed with a terminal illness and is given an unusual option by his doctor (Glenn Close) that will shield his family from the grief of losing him—at a price. Naomie Harris and Awkwafina also star.

The late rapper is the subject of a documentary by Tommy Oliver. Fans can look forward to previously unreleased music and footage from the Chicago artist.

Will Forte's MacGyver spoof, which originated first as a sketch on Saturday Night Live and made the jump to the big screen in a 2010 cult classic movie, returns now as a Peacock original series that picks up in the present day. Forte's title character has been in jail for the past decade serving a life sentence but is suddenly released as the series begins in order to participate in a secret government mission to take down an enemy from MacGruber's past, played by Billy Zane. Kristen Wiig, Ryan Phillippe, and Timothy V. Murphy also reprise their roles from the film, while new faces include Sam Elliott (as MacGruber's father) and Laurence Fishburne. Like the movie, the series is written by Forte along with John Solomon and Jorma Taccone, while the latter returns as director.

The series moves from Bravo to Peacock for its fourth season. New episodes stream weekly following today's three-episode premiere.

South Park: Post COVID: The Return of COVID Trailer Animation/Comedy Paramount+

▣ Station Eleven Trailer Drama HBO Max

Too soon? That is the big question facing this HBO Max adaptation of the award-winning 2014 novel by Emily St. John Mandel that depicts a world ravaged by a pandemic—in this case, an extremely deadly flu. The 10-episode limited series was commissioned nearly six months before the all-too-real COVID pandemic began to make headlines, and whether or not audiences are ready to treat a viral contagion as entertainment remains to be seen (though Station Eleven's far more apocalyptic scenario may make COVID seem tame and manageable by comparison). Spanning multiple timelines (but mostly focusing on the aftermath), the series comes from Patrick Somerville (Made for Love) and counts Hiro Murai (Atlanta), Helen Shaver (Vikings), and Jeremy Podeswa (Game of Thrones) among its directors. The ensemble cast includes Mackenzie Davis, Himesh Patel, David Wilmot, Matilda Lawler, Philippine Velge, Daniel Zovatto, Lori Petty, Nabhaan Rizwan, and Gael Garcìa Bernal.

Phil Augusta Jackson, a writer on critically acclaimed comedies Brooklyn Nine-Nine and Insecure, is the creator of this Los Angeles-set comedy about a group of friends who bond at a wine bar. (Yes, there are six of them—that TV rule cannot be broken.) Nicole Byer, Carl Tart, Echo Kellum, Justin Cunningham, Aaron Jennings, and Grasie Mercedes star. Tonight brings a two-episode sneak peak, though the series won't have its official premiere (and additional episodes) until January 4.

The latest workplace sitcom from Superstore creator Justin Spitzer is set in Detroit at the headquarters of a major automotive company struggling to adapt to a changing industry. The single-camera comedy stars Ana Gasteyer, jon Barinholtz, Harriet Dyer, Humphrey Ker, Michael B. Washington, Tye White and X Mayo. Two episodes air back-to-back tonight as a special sneak preview, with the series then returning for its regular run on January 4.

Joy Womack: The White Swan Trailer Documentary ($) Rent

This black-and-white film is technically an adaptation of Olaf Stapledon's 1930 sci-fi novel, but it's much more of a meditative multimedia experiment than a conventional narrative film. It's also the first and final film directed by Oscar-nominated composer Jóhann Jóhannsson, who died at the age of 48 two years before his film would make its world premiere (to excellent reviews) at the 2020 Berlinale. Men now makes its American theatrical debut today at New York's Metrograph, which will also make the film available to rent online at its website. Tilda Swinton narrates.

Co-created by SNL's Kyle Mooney along with Ben Jones (head of Bob's Burgers animation studio Bento Box), this quirky eight-episode adult comedy series inspired by '80s and '90s children's television blends live-action and animated segments, with Mooney starring as the show's twin hosts, Skip and Treybor (among other characters).

Still Out of My League Foreign/Rom-com

Twentysomethings: Austin Trailer Reality

Neflix's new Real World clone (which was titled Roaring Twenties up until a few weeks ago) spends its first season following eight 20-something strangers enlisted to live together in Austin. Episodes will arrive in two parts (six today, six on 12/17), and will likely be followed by future seasons to take place in other cities.

Sandra Bullock stars as a woman who encounters difficulty rejoining society after serving a prison sentence for committing a violent crime. Jon Bernthal and Vincent D'Onofrio also star for director Nora Fingscheidt (a German director making her English-language debut), and the Netflix film will also play in theaters beginning November 24.

THU / December 9

HBO Max's revival of the long-running HBO hit Sex and the City begins today with the first two of its 10 episodes. Formerly the show's fifth character, the city of New York has been bumped up to #4 thanks to the departure of Kim Cattrall's Samantha. But Sarah Jessica Parker, Kristin Davis, and Cynthia Nixon all reprise their co-leading roles (tempted by a $1 million per episode payday), joined by other returning faces from the original series like John Corbett's Aidan, Chris Noth's Mr. Big, Mario Cantone's Anthony, David Eigenberg's Steve, Evan Handler's Harry, and Willie Garson's Stanford. (It's the final on-screen role for the latter, who died during filming.) Newcomers include Sara Ramirez and Nicole Ari Parker.

Jodie Turner-Smith, Paapa Essiedu, Mark Stanley, and Lola Petticrew head the diverse cast for this three-part historical thriller set at the end of the titular Queen's life. Reviews were mixed-to-decent when the series premiered in the UK earlier this year.

The focus of HBO's latest "Music Box" documentary is an Australian businessman, artist manager, and producer named Robert Stigwood. He may not be a household name, but as John Maggio's film demonstrates, he is a key figure in the melding of Hollywood and the music industry. Among other achievements, he purchased the film rights to a 1976 magazine article about New York's nightclub scene and turned it into a movie called Saturday Night Fever, which spawned perhaps the most successful soundtrack album in history.

▣ Joe Pickett Trailer Drama Spectrum

▣ Landscapers Trailer Drama 9p

Delayed both by COVID and a change in directors (from Alexander Payne to Will Sharpe) after first being announced in 2019, this four-episode crime drama is based on the true story of a seemingly ordinary British married couple, Susan Edwards (played by Olivia Colman) and Christopher Edwards (David Thewlis) who become the focus of a murder investigation when two bodies are discovered in their backyard. And they aren't the bodies of two strangers, but the decade-old corpses of Susan's parents. Series writer Ed Sinclair spent hours interviewing the real-life couple, who maintain their innocence, and other participants to create the darkly comedic, perspective-shifting series, while Sharpe (who previously collaborated with Colman in the Channel 4 series Flowers) takes a highly stylized approach to the visuals. Episodes will air weekly (and stream on HBO Max) on Mondays.

David Fincher is among the producers of this six-episode collection of "visual essays" about cinema.

Ana Gasteyer and Rachel Dratch write and star in a Comedy Central original holiday movie spoof about a city dweller who moves to an almost obscenely named but quaint small town to run an inn. If you are suddenly thinking about Schitt's Creek, we're certain that's purely a coincidence.

▣ Benedetta Trailer Foreign/Drama ($) Rent

Also opening in a few theaters in LA and NY today, the latest from director Paul Verhoeven (Basic Instinct, Elle) was one of the most talked-about films at this year's Cannes, partially due to its quality (critics liked it but didn't love it) but mostly due to the fact that it's an often graphic film about a 17th century nun plagued by erotic visions who begins a steamy (and sacrilegious) affair with another nun. The adaptation of Judith C. Brown's nonfiction book Immodest Acts stars Virginie Efira, Charlotte Rampling, and Daphne Patakia.

Chasing Ghislaine Reality ID, 8p

Christmas…Again?! Family/Comedy Disney, 8p

A Christmas Dance Reunion Drama Lifeitme, 8p

▣ Citizen Ashe Trailer Documentary ($) Rent

Available both on VOD and in theaters today, this documentary from MLK/FBI director Sam Pollard, co-directing with Rex Miller (Althea), focuses on trailblazing tennis Hall of Famer and HIV/AIDS activist Arthur Ashe, who won major tournaments like Wimbledon and the U.S. and Australian Opens and was the first Black member of America's Davis Cup team. If you can wait, the film is also expected to come to CNN and HBO Max in the near future.

Cobalt Blue Foreign/Drama

▣ Deadlock Trailer Action ($) Rent/Buy

Disney's Holiday Magic Quest Trailer Reality Disney/Disney+, 7p

If you missed it on HBO Max (or in theaters), Denis Villeneuve's new take on Frank Herbert's sci-fi epic heads to premium VOD (and is also available for digital purchase) today prior to its DVD/Blu-ray release next month.

Eight Gifts of Hanukkah Drama Hallmark, 8p

Family Massacre Trailer Reality Oxygen, 9p

Funny Thing About Love Rom-com ($) Rent

▣ Harlem Trailer Comedy Prime Video

Megan Good, Grace Byers, Shoniqua Shandai, Jerrie Johnson, and Tyler LePley star (alongside guests like Whoopi Goldberg and Andrea Martin) in this 10-episode comedy series about four female friends in Harlem—think of it as a variation on Girlfriends and Sex and the City—created by Tracy Oliver (Girls Trip).

▣ PEN15 Trailer Comedy

Red Stone Action/Thriller ($) Rent

Shaun the Sheep: The Flight Before Christmas Animation/Family

Also opening in theaters today, writer-director Camille Griffin’s debut feature finds a toxic gas cloud consuming the world, while Nell (Keira Knightley), Simon (Matthew Goode), and their son Art (Jojo Rabbit's Roman Griffin Davis) are welcoming friends and family (Annabelle Wallis, Kirby Howell-Baptiste, Lily-Rose Depp, Lucy Punch, and Sope Dirisu) for one last Christmas dinner. The holiday horror comedy earned middling reviews on the festival circuit.

▣ Stath Lets Flats Comedy HBO Max

This Game's Called Murder Trailer Thriller ($) Rent

Video Music Box Documentary/Music 8p

THU / December 2

▣ The Advent Calendar Horror Shudder

▣ Annie Live! Musical/Live event 8p

NBC's latest live musical event will star Taraji P. Henson, Harry Connick Jr., Tituss Burgess, Megan Hilty, Nicole Scherzinger, and 12-year-old newcomer Celina Smith, who was cast in the lead role after a talent search.

▣ Baking It Trailer Reality competition Peacock

Cross The Great British Baking Show with NBC's Making It and you get this new feel-good, holiday-themed baking competition hosted by Maya Rudolph and Andy Samberg. Baking It comes from the same team behind Making It (including producer Amy Poehler) and will feature amateur contestants in teams of two (who will be siblings, friends, spouses, and other combinations). And the judges? A panel of four grandmothers. All six episodes stream today.

The Bitch Who Stole Christmas Trailer Comedy VH1, 9p

A Christmas Village Romance Drama Lifeitme, 8p

The Coyotes [aka Coyotes] Foreign/Drama

Great Balloon Bomb Invasion Documentary discovery+

Out of all of HBO's "Music Box" documentaries, you may think this is the one you'll want to skip. But you are wrong. The recipient of excellent reviews out of TIFF in September, Penny Lane's highly entertaining documentary knows that that the smooth jazz saxophonist (who participates in the film) is hated by as many (or more) music fans than those who adore him and buy his records by the millions. And her painstakingly researched, often humorous film doesn't just trace his life story but focuses a good chunk of time on the backlash while exploring the meaning of "good" and "bad" music through interviews with music critics, DJs, and scholars.

▣ The Pact Drama Sundance Now

Perfect Life (Vida Perfecta) Trailer Foreign/Drama/Comedy HBO Max

Queen of the Universe Reality competition Paramount+

▣ Santa Inc Trailer Animation/Comedy HBO Max

It may be a stop-motion animated holiday series in the style of your favorite Rankin/Bass classics, but Santa Inc is definitely for adults, not kids. The foul-mouthed workplace comedy (from Shrill's Alexandra Rushfield) finds Sarah Silverman voicing an elf who currently serves as a vice president at the North Pole but hopes someday to become the first female Santa. The current Santa is voiced by Seth Rogen while other voices come from Maria Bamford, Nicholas Braun, Craig Robinson, Gabourey Sidibe, and Leslie Grossman. All eight episodes stream today.

Shaq Life Reality TBS, 9p

The Whole Truth Foreign/Horror
